channel.title: Comments on: Windows and MacOS: Living In An Alternate Timeline

item.title: By: William Bowden
item.dc:creator: William Bowden
item.description:
As a Mac sys admin I can say in 25 years I now hate Apple all the jokes at me for being Apple engineer well thank you Apple for your greed and destroying a promising OS in your quest to control all, you have made me a Linux engineer and proud of it
Thanks
Of my chest now how's Utah I'm Oving UK
item.content:encoded:
As a Mac sys admin I can say in 25 years I now hate Apple all the jokes at me for being Apple engineer well thank you Apple for your greed and destroying a promising OS in your quest to control all, you have made me a Linux engineer and proud of it

Thanks

Of my chest now how’s Utah I’m Oving UK

item.title: By: josephscott
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2019/06/07/windows-and-macos-living-in-an-alternate-timeline/#comment-160226">Lefa</a>.
The better option would be to have MacOS ship with modern versions. This whole move gives me a bad feeling on where the the Unix part of MacOS is going.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Lefa.

The better option would be to have MacOS ship with modern versions. This whole move gives me a bad feeling on where the the Unix part of MacOS is going.

item.title: By: Lefa
item.dc:creator: Lefa
item.description: For macOS that just means you can install the newest version of Python, Ruby, etc using Homebrew or MacPorts. And it's also great for windows as it makes it easier to install there as well.
item.content:encoded: For macOS that just means you can install the newest version of Python, Ruby, etc using Homebrew or MacPorts. And it’s also great for windows as it makes it easier to install there as well.
